definition: Cantonese romanization/Jyutping, one of the many Cantonese romanization systems
Cantonese/short name for Guangdong 廣東|广东[Guang3 dong1]
to tell to
dialect/language/speech
to piece together/to join together/to stake all/adventurous/at the risk of one's life/to spell
sound/noise/note (of musical scale)/tone/news/syllable/reading (phonetic value of a character)
Jyutping, one of the many Cantonese romanization systems/abbr. of 粵語拼音|粤语拼音[Yue4 yu3 Pin1 yin1]
to indicate the pronunciation of Chinese characters using Pinyin or Bopomofo etc/phonetic notation/(specifically) Bopomofo (abbr. for 注音符號|注音符号[zhu4 yin1 fu2 hao4])
Cantonese language
Hanyu Pinyin, the romanization system used in the PRC since the 1960s
phonetic writing/pinyin (Chinese romanization)
Mandarin phonetic symbols (MPS), phonetic alphabet for Chinese used esp. in Taiwan, also known colloquially as Bopomofo (after the first four letters of the alphabet:ㄅㄆㄇㄈ)
the common use romanization system introduced in Taiwan in 2003
five-stroke code, Chinese character input method
reading or phonetic value of a character
the final of a Chinese syllable (the component of a syllable remaining after removal of the initial consonant, if any, and the tone, e.g. the final of "niáng" is "iang")
traditional Chinese character
the Latin alphabet
homophonic characters
see 注音符號|注音符号[zhu4 yin1 fu2 hao4]
simplified Chinese character, as opposed to traditional Chinese character 繁體字|繁体字[fan2 ti3 zi4]
pronunciation/literary (rather than colloquial) pronunciation of a Chinese character
